Heyward ... more Photo: Don Wright, Associated Press Image 9 of 9 Steelers' Heyward could face second NFL fine for honoring deceased father 1 / 9 Back to Gallery Two small words, written in white over eye black as a tribute to his late father, will cost Pittsburgh Steelers defensive end Cameron Heyward.
For the second week in a row Heyward defied the NFL and its fatuous uniform code. This being his second violation of the rules regarding the display of personal messages, it'll cost him $11,576 — he was fined $5,787 last week.
RELATED: NFL's uniform policy continues to vex
The 26-year-old's eye black featured the words "IRON" and "HEAD" — his father, former NFL fullback Craig "Ironhead" Heyward, was diagnosed with bone cancer in 1998 and died in 2006 at the age of 39.
Heyward told ESPN that he was not given permission from the NFL to wear the eye black, but the league will hear his appeal of the original fine Tuesday, per Jeremy Fowler .
Despite the looming sanction, Heyward told ESPN he has no plans to back down.
"I'm not going to shy away from the fight against cancer, and I'm going to support them in any way possible."
